answer_html: and we would need the first three values of the sequence to calculate all the following values in the sequence (\(x_{0}, x_{1},\) and \(x_{3}\)).
answer_latex:
and we would need the first three values of the sequence to calculate
all the following values in the sequence ($x_{0}, x_{1},$ and $x_{3}$).
question: 7 (a)
sols_html:
We can actually infer all the information we need to answer this question from the matrix A that was given. Let us first rewrite the matrix A in the context of how it is used:

\(\begin{bmatrix} x_{n+1}\\ x_{n}\\ x_{n-1} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_{n}\\ x_{n-1}\\ x_{n-2} \end{bmatrix}\)

This equation yields the following three linear equations:

\[\begin{aligned} x_{n+1} &= 2x_{n-1} + x_{n-2}\\ x_{n} &= x_{n}\\ x_{n-1} &= x_{n-1}\end{aligned}\]

The first equation of this set of linear equations tells us the recursive relationship for this matrix and notice that to calculate the value for the \(n^{th}\) value in the relationship where \(n > 2\) and \(n\) is an integer, we only need the first three values to be initially stated.

In summary, the recursive sequence that is inferred from A is:

\(\displaystyle x_{n+1} = 2x_{n-1} + x_{n-2}\)

and we would need the first three values of the sequence to calculate all the following values in the sequence (\(x_{0}, x_{1},\) and \(x_{3}\)).
sols_latex:
We can actually infer all the information we need to answer this
question from the matrix A that was given. Let us first rewrite the
matrix A in the context of how it is used:

$\begin{bmatrix}
x_{n+1}\\
x_{n}\\
x_{n-1}
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}

0 & 2 & 1 \\

1 & 0 & 0 \\

0 & 1 & 0

\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
x_{n}\\
x_{n-1}\\
x_{n-2}
\end{bmatrix}$

This equation yields the following three linear equations:

\begin{align*}
x_{n+1} &= 2x_{n-1} + x_{n-2}\\
x_{n} &= x_{n}\\
x_{n-1} &= x_{n-1}
\end{align*}

The first equation of this set of linear equations tells us the
recursive relationship for this matrix and notice that to calculate the
value for the $n^{th}$ value in the relationship where $n > 2$ and $n$
is an integer, we only need the first three values to be initially
stated.

In summary, the recursive sequence that is inferred from A is:

$\displaystyle x_{n+1} = 2x_{n-1} + x_{n-2}$

and we would need the first three values of the sequence to calculate
all the following values in the sequence ($x_{0}, x_{1},$ and $x_{3}$).
sols_raw:
We can actually infer all the information we need to answer this question from the matrix A that was given. Let us first rewrite the matrix A in the context of how it is used:

<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
x_{n+1}\\
x_{n}\\
x_{n-1}
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}

0 & 2 & 1 \\

1 & 0 & 0 \\

0 & 1 & 0

\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
x_{n}\\
x_{n-1}\\
x_{n-2}
\end{bmatrix}</math>

This equation yields the following three linear equations:

<math>
\begin{align}
x_{n+1} &= 2x_{n-1} + x_{n-2}\\
x_{n} &= x_{n}\\
x_{n-1} &= x_{n-1}
\end{align}</math>

The first equation of this set of linear equations tells us the recursive relationship for this matrix and notice that to calculate the value for the <math>n^{th}</math> value in the relationship where <math>n > 2</math> and <math>n </math> is an integer, we only need the first three values to be initially stated.

In summary, the recursive sequence that is inferred from A is:

<math>\displaystyle 
x_{n+1} = 2x_{n-1} + x_{n-2}</math>

and we would need the first three values of the sequence to calculate all the following values in the sequence (<math>x_{0}, x_{1},</math> and <math>x_{3}</math>).
statement_latex:
Consider the MATLAB/Octave computation

\texttt{1\textgreater{}~A={[}0~2~1;~1~0~0;~0~1~0{]}}\\\texttt{A~=~}\\\texttt{~~~0~~2~~1}\\\texttt{~~~1~~0~~0}\\\texttt{~~~0~~1~~0}

\texttt{2\textgreater{}~{[}S~D{]}=eig(A)}\\\texttt{S~=}\\\texttt{~~~0.80902~~-0.57735~~~0.30902}\\\texttt{~~~0.50000~~~0.57735~~-0.50000}\\\texttt{~~~0.30902~~-0.57735~~~0.80902}\\\texttt{D~=}\\\texttt{Diagonal~Matrix}\\\texttt{~~~1.61803~~~~~~~~~0~~~~~~~~~0}\\\texttt{~~~~~~~~~0~~-1.00000~~~~~~~~~0}\\\texttt{~~~~~~~~~0~~~~~~~~~0~~-0.61803}

\textbf{(a)} Write down a recursion relation for a sequence
\emph{x\textsubscript{0}}, \emph{x\textsubscript{1}},
\emph{x\textsubscript{2}}, \emph{x\textsubscript{3}}, ... that you can
analyse using this calculation. How many initial values do you have to
specify to define the sequence?
statement_raw:
Consider the MATLAB/Octave computation

 1> A=[0 2 1; 1 0 0; 0 1 0]
 A = 
    0  2  1
    1  0  0
    0  1  0

 2> [S D]=eig(A)
 S =
    0.80902  -0.57735   0.30902
    0.50000   0.57735  -0.50000
    0.30902  -0.57735   0.80902
 D =
 Diagonal Matrix
    1.61803         0         0
          0  -1.00000         0
          0         0  -0.61803

'''(a)''' Write down a recursion relation for a sequence ''x<sub>0</sub>'', ''x<sub>1</sub>'', ''x<sub>2</sub>'', ''x<sub>3</sub>'', ... that you can analyse using this calculation. How many initial values do you have to specify to define the sequence?
